articles.title: August is Women in Translation month: try these
articles.description: To celebrate we are featuring books from Egypt, Morocco/France, Norway, Uruguay, Argentina and Germany
articles.content: In January 1963, Enayat al-Zayyat, a young Egyptian writer, took her own life at the age of 26. Her only novel, the autobiographical Love and Silence, came out four years later. In 2019, poet Iman Mersal, following years of interviews and research, p... [7463 chars]

articles.title: One eve of vote, Argentina's Massa announces $500 mln in new loans
articles.description: In a ministry statement laying out economic policies to be formally rolled out next week, Massa also pledged to propose a "zero deficit" government budget for next year that would not overspend. Lawmakers, however, are not scheduled to take up the 2024 budget until September.
articles.content: Argentina will sign loans worth $500 million with international lenders next week, Economy Minister Sergio Massa announced on Saturday, the day before a primary election in which he is running for president to lead the embattled ruling coalition. In ... [1173 chars]

articles.title: Farrell waiting to see if he'll miss World Cup opener
articles.description: Owen Farrell will learn on Tuesday if he is to miss England's critical World Cup opener against Argentina after he was sent off for a dangerous tackle against Wales.
articles.content:

articles.title: England 19-17 Wales: Owen Farrell could miss World Cup opener after 'bunker' red card
articles.description: England captain Owen Farrell could miss their World Cup opener against Argentina after being sent off in their warm-up win over Wales at Twickenham.
articles.content:
Owen Farrell was initially shown a yellow card before the new 'Bunker' review system upgraded the decision to a sending off

articles.title: Argentine farmers back conservatives in election, hoping for freer markets
articles.description: In Argentina's grains fields and cattle ranches, farmers are hoping upcoming elections will bring political change and an end to years of economic uncertainty, ushering in freer markets with fewer currency controls and export limits. The South American country will vote in open primary elections on Sunday that will give an indication of how general elections in October will go.
articles.content:

articles.title: Argentina's markets keep wary eye on primary vote after 2019 crash
articles.description: Argentine traders are keeping a close eye on primary elections on Sunday, which will reveal the likely outcome of the Oct. 22 general ballot, with a major market crash after the same vote in 2019 still seared in their memories.
articles.content: A man wearing a face mask as a protective measure against the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) walks past the entrance of the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange, a day after midterm primary elections, in Buenos Aires, Argentina September 13, 2021. REUTERS/Agu... [3224 chars]
